story:
The annual Charity Fundraising appeal at Molescroft Primary School is having to be even more creative than normal this year.  As everyone adjusts to the regulations connected to Covid 19 in 2020, clearly things have to be very different.

Talent and entertainment shows were always a huge part of the Charity Fundraising Programme and therefore each class is providing an "act" to go into a very special show, our own special "Telethon" which we are sharing with our community from the evening of Friday 20 November 2020.  The show will be available through a link on the school website.

I hope that all our community will come together to watch the children's performances and a number of special surprises including the popular "Teachers Got Talent", as we come together to raise money for Macmillan Cancer Support.  This charity has been selected to show our appreciation for the support of Macmillan Cancer Care for our dear teacher Martin Wood and his family.  Martin passed away two days before the start of the Autumn Term this year.

In addition we shall launch a special Charity Single in the show, which will feature all our pupils and which will be available to download.  It is called "Right There With You".

We thank everyone for their support, generosity, care and understanding.

Nothing can prepare you and your loved ones for the such a potentially life changing event as a diagnosis of cancer or other critical health condition but there are things that you can and should put in place now to support you and you family; from the onset of symptoms through to diagnosis and treatment; as well as providing the peace of mind that your families future financial security is assured.

I am so grateful that I took heed of this advice (mostly!) a few years ago as it gives me great comfort to know that these boringly practical but vitally important elements have been taken care of, as I just cannot imagine trying to deal with these matters in the midst of emotional armageddon.

Private Health Insurance – I cannot stress enough how beneficial private health cover can be in ensuring an early diagnosis of a potentially life changing condition. Unfortunately, having enjoyed this benefit during my executive career, I did not retain this once I became self employed. As a consequence, it took almost 12 weeks from the onset of symptoms and an incorrect diagnosis of cracked ribs, muscle strain, muscle tear, wind and even pleurisy before eventually being granted the all-important CT scan that revealed the cancer and allowed treatment to begin. - If your employer offers it, take it; if they do not, seriously consider funding it yourself (if able).

Life Insurance/Critical Illness Cover - I am guessing that most of you will/should have life insurance policies in place that will help soften the financial burden for you family if the unthinkable happens? However, advances in medical science have thankfully resulted in much improved survival rates for many illnesses that were previously fatal. In this case, critical illness cover can provide much needed financial support when you are no longer able to work and provide for your family! - Like all insurance, it’s not needed until you need it and although expensive, it buys peace of mind!

Retain a Financial Advisor – Often in a relationship one party (husband, wife, partner) takes care of the majority of financial, legal and insurance matters, often without the involvement or understanding of the other. If the unthinkable happens, would you or your partner know what savings accounts, insurance policies, pension etc are in place and where to access all the documents/information? I would strongly recommend retaining the services of a trusted financial advisor that you both like and have complete confidence in; someone who gets to know your family, its wishes and aspirations and is fully conversant and involved with your financial planning and protection. For a number of years, I have retained and can thoroughly recommend Chris.Bull@kelland.co.uk who has always provided good counsel and has been an absolute rock during the past couple of weeks in dealing with any financial concerns.

Get a Will in Place– My wife and I avoided this subject for years but, after good advice, put one in place earlier this year thereby, thankfully, avoiding being forced to address this now. - I strongly suggest that, if you do not have one in place, do so NOW. A basic Will is not expensive and can be drafted via most local solicitors, but if you need something more complex involving Family Trusts or Powers of Attorney then seek more specialist advice. We used and can recommend Paul.Clark@spallclark.co.uk

Death in Service Benefit – Not usually top of the list when negotiating your remuneration package with a potential new employer and my guess is that many of you will not actually know your current entitlement without checking first! This can provide the peace of mind in knowing that if the unthinkable happens, your family will at least have a degree of financial security. Again, it’s not that expensive for your employer to increase your cover and when it’s time for your annual pay review, why not suggest an increase in the DiS multiple rather than increasing your basic pay or even take a salary sacrifice to help pay for the increased premium.


We all think we are invincible, and it happens to other people, so we put off making these types of decisions on the basis that’s its expensive, not required or I will sort it later. In reality it can and probably will happen to many of you or your loved ones (sorry!) and I seriously urge you to ‘plan for the worst but hope for the best’ in relation to planning for the future.

If this advice now prompts you into taking action then it’s been extremely worthwhile and all I ask in return is that you take time to reflect what is REALLY important in your life and to treasure/protect it as you never know what’s around the corner …………..and maybe ask you all to make a donation to Macmillan Cancer Support charity through my just Giving page 

Also, If you are prompted to take out life insurance, critical health cover, private health, make a will or appoint a financial advisor, please ask the companies involved to also make a contribution

I've decided to sign up to run 5k for 10 days straight to try raise some pennies for Macmillan Cancer Support. I'm not really too sure why, out of all the things I could've chosen, I have decided to pick this challenge, when my motivation for fitness is at an all time low and my weight is at an all time high (it could be the start of a mid-life crisis) but I'm sure the cold, dark, wet nights of me plodding around Rodley and surrounding areas will be fun. I have chosen to start on Monday 7th December so I can combine this challenge with The Big Leeds Santa Dash 2020 5k run that I have also signed up for which will be held at Temple Newsam on 13th December and will be raising money for St. Gemma's Hospice.

I know that funds are tight for a lot of people nowadays, especially with Christmas on the horizon, but I'd be extremely grateful if you could sponsor me as much or as little as you can for such a great cause.

Big love and thank yous

story:

Aelfryn Lloyd Jones 1942 – 2020

Aelfryn was a fantastic dad and husband.  He had a great, fulfilling life.  Aelfryn had his first heart attack in his early forties, his second in his fifties, and was diagnosed with heart failure just after retirement in his sixties.  This year, he was diagnosed with lung cancer. Aelfryn died of late stage Heart Failure on 11 November this year at the age of 78.  Aelfryn always asked his family for donations to his two chosen charities:  British Heart Foundation and Cancer Research UK. We would very much appreciate it if you could donate in his honour and to celebrate his life with us.  Thank you – The Jones Family x

story:
Thank you for taking the time to read this, pop onto my page or make a donation.  It is very much appreciated but me and my entire family.


GOSH are an incredible hospital who care for so many children every single day.  

The past 6 1/2 years have been tough. Having a baby who has lots of different medical issues and conditions which require multiple stays in hospital, surgeries, tests, investigations and other procedures is really tough.  Having to travel to London, where it is difficult to have visitors and we have to be away from Charlie's sister and Dad makes it that much harder.  There is nobody to visit Charlie, so he just gets my face to look at! There is nobody to come and take over so I can have a break.  Through all of this GOSH make it easier.  They listen to everything we have to say and always take my opinions on board as his Mum, they make Charlie feel as relaxed as possible, making him feel like the superstar he is. They talk us through everything they will be doing and why.  The play leaders make the children feel special and take their mind off everything they are going through. 


I wish I could put into words just how grateful we all are to have all the amazing staff at GOSH care for our best boy

story:
It's that time again :)

The time for giving....

For the past 5 years at dunnhumby, we have donated gifts for children who unfortunately spend Christmas in GOSH by placing them underneath our Christmas trees on the 23rd of December they get collected and dropped off to the hospital by myself and colleagues .

The project was started after my son had a cardiac arrest and unable to breath for himself after the arrest, he spent 7 months in GOSH where the doctors did everything they could to save him. They managed to get him up and running again and as gesture of appreciation to the hospital, we started collecting donations in every shape or form to support them as an organisation.

Once again, this year we are collecting donations for the same cause but in a slightly different way. Due to COVID-19 we are only collecting donations online instead of physical gifts.

Please donate whatever you can.. no amount is too little or too large.

We aim to hand all donations in on the 23rd of December 2020

Thank you for your continued support!

story:
This Football Shirt Friday, the Bobby Moore Fund is calling on you, football fans across the nation, to wear your favourite shirt, donate and share a selfie to raise vital funds to help tackle bowel cancer.

Bobby Moore was just 51 years old when he died. Shortly after his death in 1993, Bobby’s widow Stephanie Moore MBE set up the Bobby Moore Fund as a restricted fund of Cancer Research UK to raise money for pioneering bowel cancer research.

Since Bobby’s death, the generosity of our supporters has enabled us to raise over £27 million and mortality rates for bowel cancer have fallen by more than 30%.

But sadly the disease still kills 45 people in the UK every day, showing we still have a long way to go to achieve our goal of tackling bowel cancer.

Aelfryn died of late stage Heart Failure on 11 November this year at the age of 78.  Aelfryn always asked his family for donations to his two chosen charities:  British Heart Foundation and Cancer Research UK. pageSummary: We are Lighting Up Christmas because families are facing their last Christmas together.
pageSummaryWhy: families are facing their last Christmas together.
story:
This year, we need local businesses and companies to come together to Light Up Christmas for Marie Curie’s Surrey Nursing Service. We have an ambitious target of raising £12,800 which will fund the service for the 12 days of Christmas, meaning our Nurses can help the people they care for make the most of what could be their final Christmas with their loved ones.

By donating unused Christmas party funds, passing an e-card around or hosting a festive fundraising event with colleagues - you can make a huge difference to families living in your community.

Families like Helen’s.

XXXX

We need you to come together with businesses and communities across Surrey to help us be there for many more families like Helen’s this Christmas. By helping us Light Up Christmas, you’ll ensure that our Nurses can be there for families who are facing their last one together.


There are two ways you can get involved and support the campaign.

Make a donation – simply click the donate button at the top. You may decide to donate what you would normally spend on a Christmas Party or Christmas cards.

Set up a JustGiving page for staff fundraising – we have lots of festive
fundraising ideas which we can share with you, and here are just a few examples

  • You could hold a virtual festive jumper day with a prize for the wackiest jumper or a ‘dec your desk’ competition, with a special ‘video call tea break’ for the judging to take place.
  • If your staff are working from home, you could suggest they donate the cost of their normal weekly commute, or the price of their morning coffee.

To thank you if you set up a JustGiving page or donating over £20 to our page we will:

  • Hang a tag with your company name or logo on the Christmas Tree that will go up in our Care Co-ordination Centre in Caterham (Surrey) in December, so our Nursing Team can see your support in-between patient visits. Once the campaign comes to an end, we’ll also share your support on Marie Curie’s South East social media pages.
  • Provide you with a choice of custom Christmas e-cards to send to your staff, customers, clients, suppliers and friends, encouraging them to support too.
  • Provide festive fundraising ideas.


Every penny donated or raised really will make a huge difference and help us Light Up Christmas for the Surrey Nursing Service. Here are just a few examples of how the funds will help over the festive period:

  • £1 will put a pen torch in the pocket of a Marie Curie Nurse, so they can do vital examinations of the people in their care.
  • £20 will fund an hour of expert care and support for someone living with a terminal illness in the comfort of their own home over the Christmas period.
  • £180 will pay for a night shift for a Marie Curie Nurse so that the patient’s family can take a well-earned rest knowing their loved one is well looked after.
  • £1,600 will sponsor a Marie Curie nurse for the twelve days of Christmas.
  • £12,800 will fund the Surrey Nursing Service for the 12 days of Christmas, meaning we can help families make the most of what could be their final Christmas together.

For more information or to get involved, please contact us on 07884 264870 or email Luisa.Stevens1@mariecurie.org.uk

We really hope you will consider supporting our patients, their families and our Nurses this Christmas.

Thank you, and Merry Christmas!

story:
We're here to support people with serious illnesses in the Newcastle area to have the best quality of life possible, whatever that might mean for them.

Our hospice team includes doctors, nurses, physiotherapists, social workers and many more, and is supported by over 100 volunteers, who play a vital role in the running of the hospice. 

Some people stay in our 20-bed in-patient unit, where relatives and friends can visit any time of the day or night, and stay with their loved ones if they wish.

Our day therapy unit offers outpatient clinics and a wide range of activities and therapies, including baking, art therapy and relaxation. 

We also provide support for carers and families, including our social work team who provide emotional and practical advice. Our chaplain is here to provide spiritual care to patients and their loved ones.

Thank you for supporting us, and helping to make sure more people with a terminal illness in the Newcastle area get the care and support they need.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit this JustGiving page set up in Ash’s name. Ash is my 18 year old now living on in the next life. 

Ash was born in Whitby on 14th January 2002.  Ash was always a very kind and caring child.  Ash followed me in being a human rights campaigner and attended various national demonstrations from a young age.  Amongst causes close to Ash’s heart was the conflict in Palestine and at only age 8 Ash spoke about this in a school assembly.  It was a proud moment to see Ash stood there with the microphone at such a young age.  Because of Ash, the school raised money for the British Red Cross charity.

For many years it was just Ash and me but then Ash was over the moon to have a little sister – Ruqayya, or as Ash would say ‘Ruqi Cookie’.  Ash was present during pregnancy scans of Ruqi and supported me when I nearly lost the baby.  Ruqi was born a healthy baby at home with Ash supporting me throughout labour while being only aged 9.  

Ash loved holidays and had visited Disneyland Paris, Turkey, Egypt and Morocco.  Ash was also a lover of theme-parks and the family held annual passes as they visited so often.  Ash loved surprises and last year loved it when I woke Ash and Ruqi up at the crack of dawn to go on a surprise trip to Chessington World of Adventures.  Ash loved short breaks with family to London also. Madame Tussauds was a favourite.  For Ash’s 18th, I arranged for the two of us to go swimming with sharks.  That was an amazing experience.  More recently Ash went on a 3 night break to Blackpool with a college friend.

After finishing school Ash was successful in getting a place at College to study Health and Social Care.  Ash carried out work experience working with people with learning disabilities.  Caring came naturally to Ash and as Ash had grown up with a cousin with learning disabilities this work was more than within Ash’s capabilities.  

Alongside college, Ash had a part time job at Greggs the Bakery.  Like most teenagers Ash wasn’t too keen on the work but loved earning the money.  It was also a bonus to get a half price discount card and Ash liked to bring home cakes for  us all.  Ash enjoyed treating me and sister Ruqi to a takeaway courtesy of Ash’s wages.  The family are so proud of Ash for getting and maintaining a job, especially in the current climate.  Ash was always reliable, honest and polite.  Ash was progressing well in learning to drive too and was looking forward to getting a car in the future.  Ash was a Director of a social care company set up this year where Ash and I were offering social care support and training.  Ash enjoyed speaking at events.  Ash was planning to progress to University to study Social Work like me. Ash wanted to work with troubled young people.  

Ash had grown up around such a diverse group of people and had friends from a wide range of backgrounds.  There was absolutely no hate in Ash – only love and kindness and a desire to help those in need.  In Ash’s teenage years the family took part in more national human rights demonstrations and charity events.  Ash took an active part in an anti -Donald Trump protest a couple of years ago in London.  Ash took part in sponsored walks over a few years to support a maternity unit in Gaza, Palestine.  Ash enjoyed helping others.

Ash was very kind in visiting elderly great grandparents and was always respectful and kind.  As well as being kind to people, Ash loved animals.  Ash’s cats over the years have been called Cool Cat, Dude and Stormzy Coco Bean. Ash also loved food, especially KFC and Nandos.  Ash would often buy extra food in order to feed a homeless person.

Ash was loved by everyone and had many friends over the years.  Ash’s family are heart broken at this great loss.  Ash achieved so much in so few years.  We ask that you please remember Ash in your prayers and pray for Ash to be in the best of the heavens.   The Prophet Mohammed, peace be upon him is reported to have said, “heaven lies beneath the feet of your mother”, that is to say, serving our mothers is one of the most rewarded deeds.  Ash has been an amazing child and young adult and God, the all knowing will know this.  As Ash’s mum, I could not be more proud of what Ash has become.

Please let us all follow Ash’s example in showing kindness to all, even if it’s just in the form of a smile. If you are able to give financially then please consider donating on this page in memory of Ash.

story:
Why? 


Here at Leo HQ, we like to do something charitable each year and this year is no different. In fact, this year we believe it is more important than ever to raise a helping hand and be part of making a difference. In uncertain times, clean water is more important than ever. 


To highlight why want to help this cause: 


  • 785 million people worldwide don’t have access to clean water 

  • 2019 was the second hottest year the world has ever faced

  • 1 in 4 children will live in places where water is alarmingly scarce by 2040


People in Ethiopia and all around the world, need clean water to stay safe and healthy, protect their families, and build a better future for themselves. 


This is why we have decided to help by creating our own challenge, For every person who successfully completes our challenge and shares to social media, Leo will be donating £1. 


Let’s raise some money!
